You can specify the image, ports, environment variables, etc., based on your requirements.Implement the setup and teardown methods using @BeforeEach and @AfterEach annotations respectively. In the setup method, start the container using the container.start() method. In the teardown method, stop the container using container.stop().Write your test methods, utilizing the containerized environment as needed. Testcontainers will automatically manage the lifecycle of the container, starting it before your tests run and stopping it afterward.Here's an example to help illustrate the steps:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Remember to replace "my-container-image:latest" with the actual name and tag of the container image you want to use.That's the basic idea of running a Java class inside a container using Testcontainers. https://chat.openai.com/share/b4499007-1.Prompt: How to instrument a spring bean to log when the bean is used
https://chat.openai.com/share/b4499007-1.Answer: To instrument a Spring bean to log when it is used, you can follow these steps:Add a logging framework to your project if you haven't already. Popular logging frameworks in the Java ecosystem include Log4j, SLF4J, and Logback.Enable component scanning in your Spring configuration to automatically detect and create bean instances. You can do this by adding @ComponentScan or @SpringBootApplication annotations to your configuration class.Create an aspect using Spring AOP (Aspect-Oriented Programming) to intercept the bean usage. An aspect is a modular unit of cross-cutting concern that defines specific behavior to be executed at certain join points in your application. Here's an example aspect to log bean usage:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Adjust the package and class names in the aspect according to your project's structure. The example above assumes your bean is located in the com.yourpackage package, and its class name is YourBean.Ensure that your logging configuration is properly set up to capture the log statements. This typically involves specifying the log levels and the output destination for the logs.With these steps in place, whenever a method within your bean (YourBean) is called, the logBeanUsage() method in the BeanUsageLoggerAspect aspect will be triggered, and it will log a message indicating that the bean was used.Note that for this approach to work, the bean in question must be created by Spring's dependency injection mechanism. If the bean is created manually using the new keyword, Spring AOP won't be able to intercept its method invocations.Remember to adjust the code according to your specific requirements and project setup.

I can guide you through the process of creating a simple Android application using Room database to store and retrieve data, and Java programming language. We'll create a table called "sticker_data" with columns ID, PACKNAME, CREATORNAME, PACKICON, and STICKERLIST.Before we begin, make sure you have Android Studio installed and set up on your computer. Let's get started!Step 1: Set up the projectOpen Android Studio and create a new project.Choose an application name, domain, and project location.Select "Empty Activity" as the template for the project.Click "Finish" to create the project.Step 2: Add dependenciesOpen the build.gradle file for the app module.Add the following dependencies:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Step 3: Create the StickerData classRight-click on the package name in the project structure and select "New" -> "Java Class".Name the class StickerData and click "OK".Add the following code to the StickerData class:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Step 4: Create the StickerDataDao interfaceRight-click on the package name in the project structure and select "New" -> "Java Class".Name the class StickerDataDao and click "OK".Add the following code to the StickerDataDao interface:[CODE_BLOCK_2]Step 5: Create the StickerDatabase classRight-click on the package name in the project structure and select "New" -> "Java Class".Name the class StickerDatabase and click "OK".Add the following code to the StickerDatabase class:[CODE_BLOCK_3]Step 6: Set up the Room DatabaseOpen the MainActivity class.Add the following code to the onCreate method to initialize the Room database:[CODE_BLOCK_4]Step 7: Store and retrieve data using Room DatabaseTo store data, use the following code:[CODE_BLOCK_5]Replace "Pack Name", "Creator Name", "pack_icon_uri", and stickerList with appropriate values.To retrieve data, use the following code:[CODE_BLOCK_6]That's it! You've created a simple Android application using Room database to store and retrieve data. Remember to handle permissions for accessing the device's storage if you plan to work with URIs. Feel free to customize the code according to your requirements and UI design.

ListOfCode.Content:
StickerDatabase stickerDatabase = Room.databaseBuilder(getApplicationContext(), StickerDatabase.class, "sticker_db").build();
StickerDataDao stickerDataDao = stickerDatabase.stickerDataDao();

StickerData stickerData = new StickerData("Pack Name", "Creator Name", "pack_icon_uri", stickerList);
stickerDataDao.insertStickerData(stickerData);

Similarly, when the value is set to "serviceB", the ServiceB implementation will be loaded and autowired.Remember to adjust the property key and values according to your specific needs.

https://chat.openai.com/share/85a33a1a-8.Prompt: android llm adblocker. help me write it. I'm using gpt4all to run the llm on the phone. All of the content of the connections should be sent to the vpn, and then it should be able to decide what connections to block and not block.
https://chat.openai.com/share/85a33a1a-8.Answer: Creating an Android Adblocker using GPT-4 LLM is quite involved, so I'll give you an outline to get started. In this approach, we'll create a local VPN service on the device which will intercept traffic. This service will then utilize the LLM to determine whether a connection should be blocked or allowed based on the content.Setting Up the VPN Service:Android allows developers to create a local VPN service using the VpnService API. This doesn't actually create a real VPN connection, but it lets your app inspect and modify network packets. This is perfect for our ad-blocking purpose.Using the LLM to Analyze Traffic:For each request captured by the VPN service, you'll send the URL, headers, and possibly content (though that may be overkill for ad blocking) to your GPT-4 LLM. It will then determine whether to allow or block the connection.Here's a basic outline for the implementation:1. Set up the VPN Service:Add the necessary permission to the AndroidManifest.xml:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Create a VPN Service:[CODE_BLOCK_1]2. Analyze Traffic with LLM:Assuming you have a method like shouldBlock(String url) -> boolean, you can send each URL to your LLM and get a decision on whether to block it.[CODE_BLOCK_2]3. Decision Making:In your VPN Service, for each connection:[CODE_BLOCK_3]Notes:Android VPN services can't analyze encrypted traffic (HTTPS) directly. A typical way ad-blockers work around this is by looking at DNS requests. If a known ad-related domain is requested, they block that connection.While GPT-4 LLM can certainly help in making decisions, traditional ad-blockers use maintained lists of known ad-related domains. Using LLM will be more resource-intensive and may not be as effective as tried-and-true blocklists.Always respect user privacy. When analyzing traffic with LLM or any other system, ensure that personal data is not sent or logged in any way.Do note that there are legal and store policy considerations when developing ad-blockers, especially if you intend to distribute them on platforms like the Google Play Store.Lastly, if you're serious about creating such an application, it's important to have a solid foundation in Android development and networking, and always keep the user's privacy and security in mind.

https://chat.openai.com/share/85a33a1a-8.Prompt: Why not implement it as a http proxy
https://chat.openai.com/share/85a33a1a-8.Answer: Implementing an ad-blocker as an HTTP proxy is a viable approach and offers certain advantages. Using an HTTP proxy, you can intercept, inspect, and modify HTTP requests and responses, making it easier to filter out ads or unwanted content.Advantages of using an HTTP proxy approach:Simplified Traffic Inspection: Since you're dealing with HTTP/HTTPS traffic directly, you can inspect headers, content, and URLs in a straightforward manner.Better Control: A proxy setup allows for more granular control over the traffic. You can modify requests and responses, cache responses, or even inject your own content if needed.Ease of Integration: Users can set the proxy for specific WiFi networks, allowing them to choose where they want ad-blocking to be active. Also, a proxy can be used across devices, not just Android, if the proxy server is reachable.Support for HTTPS: With proper setup (and user consent), the proxy can inspect HTTPS traffic, allowing for more effective blocking.Steps for Implementing as an HTTP Proxy:Set Up the Proxy Server: There are many open-source proxy server libraries/tools available. One popular option for Java-based applications is LittleProxy.Integration with GPT-4 LLM: Once you intercept a request, send relevant details (like URL, headers) to the LLM for analysis.[CODE_BLOCK_0]Handle the Traffic: Based on the LLM's recommendation, either forward the request to its destination, block it, or modify it.User Setup: On the user's device, they will need to set the WiFi's HTTP proxy settings to point to the IP address and port where your proxy server is running.Considerations:HTTPS Handling: To inspect HTTPS traffic, the proxy will need to perform a man-in-the-middle (MITM) action. This requires generating and installing a custom certificate on the user's device. While effective, it raises privacy concerns, and users should be fully informed.Performance: Running an HTTP proxy (especially one that communicates with a model like GPT-4 for decision-making) might have a performance overhead. Ensure the implementation is efficient, and caching frequent decisions might help.Privacy: Always respect user privacy. Ensure personal data isn't sent, stored, or logged. Inform users about the data you're inspecting, especially if performing MITM on HTTPS traffic.In summary, while an HTTP proxy offers more direct control over web traffic, it also requires careful implementation to ensure user privacy and performance.

https://chat.openai.com/share/b0e9f648-2.Prompt: How create an immutable map in Java
https://chat.openai.com/share/b0e9f648-2.Answer: In Java, you can create an immutable map using the java.util.Collections class. The Collections class provides a method called unmodifiableMap() that takes a map as input and returns an unmodifiable (immutable) view of the map. Here's an example:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In the above example, we create a mutable map using HashMap, and then we pass it to Collections.unmodifiableMap() to obtain an immutable view of the map. Any attempt to modify the immutable map will result in an UnsupportedOperationException. However, the original mutable map can still be modified.Please note that the immutability of the map applies only to the map itself, not the objects it contains. If the map contains mutable objects, those objects can still be modified. To create a fully immutable map, you would need to make sure that the values in the map are also immutable or make defensive copies when adding objects to the map.

https://chat.openai.com/share/688e6e75-6.Prompt:
Right now I got stuck on accessing files on Android.
I'm using https://www.npmjs.com/package/react-native-document-picker which opens native file explorer and allows to choose one or multiple files. It then returns the information about those files, including URI. URI on Android is returned in a form of "content://".

This works fine. The problem begins with accessing the file (reading):

07-04 15:09:03.050 21232 21351 W System.err: java.lang.SecurityException: Permission Denial: reading com.android.providers.media.MediaDocumentsProvider uri content://com.android.providers.media.documents/document/document:1000003887 from pid=21232, uid=10403 requires that you obtain access using ACTION_OPEN_DOCUMENT or related APIs
I added <uses-permission android:name="android.permission.READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE"/> (and WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE, and MANAGE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE just in case) to AndroidManifest but that did not work.
I also added android:requestLegacyExternalStorage="true" (though it should not work anymore according to docs).
I think that's because Android requires runtime permissions for some actions since SDK version 23: https://reactnative.dev/docs/permissionsandroid.html
I see that list of "Permissions that require prompting the user" includes READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE.
I've tried their snippet, however right now instead of prompt asking about permission I'm getting (in the logs) information that I just don't have permission to access storage.
I also don't have any permissions listed in app's settings.

This is what I've looked at (and other):
itinance/react-native-fs#395
RonRadtke/react-native-blob-util#118
itinance/react-native-fs#676
itinance/react-native-fs#756 (comment)

For a moment I thought that the problem lies in Scoped Storage but I consulted Wiktor and it's probably not the case: https://blog.notesnook.com/scoped-storage-in-react-native/
https://chat.openai.com/share/688e6e75-6.Answer: The problem you're encountering is not uncommon. Since Android 10 (API level 29), due to Scoped Storage, apps do not have unrestricted access to the file system. Instead, apps have access to app-specific directories and media files. This is not related to permissions you're requesting in AndroidManifest.xml - that's a different issue.The error message you're seeing requires that you obtain access using ACTION_OPEN_DOCUMENT or related APIs means that Android wants you to use Storage Access Framework (SAF) APIs to access the file.The react-native-document-picker library you're using handles file selection correctly. The URI that's returned is a content URI, and Android expects you to use content resolvers to access the file data.The good news is that you don't need to ask for the READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE permission if you're using this library. The ACTION_OPEN_DOCUMENT permission implicitly grants read access to the selected file, regardless of its actual location on the filesystem.Here's a basic example of how you could read file data from a content URI in a React Native Android module:[CODE_BLOCK_0]You need to call this method from your React Native JavaScript code with the URI you received from react-native-document-picker:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Note that you have to replace YourModule with the actual name of your native module. This is a very basic example, you would probably want to do something more meaningful with the data read from the InputStream.Finally, you mentioned that your app does not have any permissions listed in its settings. This might indicate that there's something wrong with how you're requesting permissions. Make sure that you're correctly requesting permissions at runtime if you need them for other parts of your app.
